summary: This 1958 Court of Appeal decision in Ghana addressed an application by the Okyenhene of Akyem Abuakwa for a writ of prohibition to halt proceedings by a Stool Boundaries Settlement Commissioner. The core issue was a breach of natural justice, specifically the audi alteram partem rule, as the Commissioner refused counsel's request to cross-examine the principal witness, Nene Mate Kole of Manya Krobo, on historical diaries and records used in the inquiry. Additionally, the Commissioner was accused of pre-judging issues in the Manya Krobo boundary inquiry based on findings from the Akwamu inquiry, where Akyem Abuakwa was not a party. The Court found that denying cross-examination and prior hearing constituted a serious departure from natural justice, warranting the grant of a writ of prohibition to prevent further unjust proceedings.
citations: R. v. Wandsworth Justices, ex p. Read [1924] 1 K.B. 281
R. v. North, ex p. Oakey [1927] 1 K.B. 491
Halsbury's Laws of England (3rd ed.), Vol. 11, p. 64
rationaleHighlights: Denial of cross-examination violates natural justice
Tribunal must allow parties to be heard before deciding issues
Use of evidence from one inquiry to prejudge another is improper
Pre-judgment on contested land without hearing all parties is a jurisdictional flaw
Rules of natural justice apply to quasi-judicial bodies
Prohibition is an appropriate remedy for breach of fair hearing
Affidavit evidence is admissible in prohibition applications
Failure to serve notice on a contiguous party undermines procedural fairness
